thread.section_title: Biz Dailies: Business and Financial News Feed
thread.title: Dairy company Bega posts a profit but warns of challenging times ahead - Australia Broadcasting Corporation
thread.title_full: Dairy company Bega posts a profit but warns of challenging times ahead - Australia Broadcasting Corporation

title: Dairy company Bega posts a profit but warns of challenging times ahead - Australia Broadcasting Corporation
text:
By Brett Worthington Updated February 22, 2017 11:00:18 Map: Bega 2550 
Dairy company Bega Cheese has posted a $15.7 million after-tax profit in its half-year results. 
In an announcement to the stock exchange, the company said its profit was up more than 8 per cent, or $1.2 million, on the same period last year. 
Chairman Barry Irvin said he expected the second half of the financial year would be more challenging than the previous six months. 
But he expected full-year earnings would be in line with last year. 
Bega's net profit after tax rose 132 per cent to $28.8 million in the 2015-16 financial year. 
Revenue in that year rose 7 per cent to $1.2 billion and there was a 56 per cent lift in earnings to $65.4 million. 
The company also cut its debt to $53.1 million, down 9.6 per cent during in the last year. 
Bega's press releases stated the downward trend in global dairy commodity prices was showing signs of recovery, while the infant formula market had become more volatile. 
"While nutritionals [are] experiencing challenges this year, the ingredients market is improving rapidly," chief executive Paul van Heerwaarden said. 
"We always remain alert to changes in the market and supply and demand dynamics, endeavouring to position ourselves to be agile enough to meet challenges and respond to opportunities." Photo: Shares in Bega rallied after the company announced it had agreed to a deal that would return Vegemite to Australian ownership. (Nikolai Beilharz) Rollercoaster year for Bega shares amid dairy industry crisis 
It has been a tumultuous six months for Bega as the dairy industry battled its ongoing price crisis . 
Late last year, shares in Bega hit a 52-week low as investors continued to offload shares in the dairy processor. 
It came after the company admitted sales of its infant formula to Asia had not lived up to expectation . 
Shares rallied in January when the company announced it would buy most of Mondelez International's Australia and New Zealand grocery and cheese business. 
The deal attracted headlines because it meant Vegemite would return to Australian ownership . 
The deal does not include Philadelphia products but will see Australian ownership of Kraft-branded products, including peanut butter, cheeses and mayonnaise.
